Uploaded patch set 27: Commit message was updated.

Why?  Please answer in your commit message.


If bmcweb is launched.... the bmc is clearly ON.

bmc state supports other states as well
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/State/BMC.interface.yaml#L46

this commit represents all other possible states by reading state manager
This feels more "Enabled" to me but I'm not super strong on that.

there is no Enabled enum.

can we can set as  "On"

"PowerState": {
            "enum": [
                "On",
                "Off",
                "PoweringOn",
                "PoweringOff",
                "Paused"
            ],
            "enumDescriptions": {
                "Off": "The state is powered off.",
                "On": "The state is powered on.",
                "Paused": "The state is paused.",
                "PoweringOff": "A temporary state between on and off.",
                "PoweringOn": "A temporary state between off and on."
            },

I think On makes more sense

We probably want to add this to the bmcweb service file:
After=xyz.openbmc_project.State.BMC
ok, I think its not needed if state manager starts first before bmcweb?
Please delete this code now that the phosphor-bmc-state interface is being used to determine State.
When update is in progress, the PowerState "On" makes more sense

Yes. But i feel the ["Status"]["State"] = "Updating" will indicate that the code update is in progress.
The PowerState is On - to indicate that the BMC is on and running good.
Yeah, I'd vote we make it "On" for everything. i.e. if the BMC can return state then it's power is On. The "State" is where you provide the more detailed info about what the BMC is doing.
Sorry, should have been clear in that last comment. I think this should be "On" as well. The "State" will indicate the BMC is still "Starting".

CI failed with CLANG errors which are not related to this commit.
Tried to rebase but still it fails
I think it's because you are missing a "}"
Can you PoweringOn for the PowerState when we aren't ready? Otherwise looks good
please look at above discussion about the same where Andrew suggested to keep it as "ON"
Where? I see a bunch of discussion around not using PoweringOn for UpdateInProgress but nothing around PoweringOn for NotReady
Yeah, its suggested to make it "On" for everything. i.e. if the BMC can return state then it's power is On. The "State" is where it provides the more detailed info about what the BMC is doing.

So this is the comment:
"Yeah, I'd vote we make it "On" for everything. i.e. if the BMC can return state then it's power is On. The "State" is where you provide the more detailed info about what the BMC is doing." ?

I still think PoweringOn makes more sense but I guess 🤷
@EdTonous can you please do merge review?
Gerrit shows a "Merge Conflict". Looks like you need a rebase Ravi.

I think state management is one it is fine calling directly (we do other places). 

If this interface doesn't exist, you would not get a Status/PowerState but I think that is fine. Some places we do have a default but everyone should have this interface, if they don't, leaving off seems reasonable (leave off properties you don't have information on, more in line with the Redfish spec IMO)

I guess, we don't need any changes here.
marking as resolved

Gunnar
please look at discussion about this in last few patchsets , Andrew and Sunitha suggested to use enum "On" as state provides detailed state
Please wrap your commits properly.  50/72 please
Given the comment I made below, this doesn't appear to be true, and you've deleted the code that sets the BMC state to "starting"

CurrentBMCState is settable.
I mean, have tested this patch with all possible bmc states
yep, you can manually set the BMC state over d-bus for testing
@Edtonous @Gunnar can you please merge this commit?
@EdTonous @Gunnar can you please do merge for this commit?

Please write a more complete commit message;  The commit message should answer "why", and needs to include why for the whole commit, including why we're moving away from systemd here (which is the standard interface for this).
This doesn't appear answered in the latest commit.
added more detail of client use case

Isn't this going to break existing users that relied on the systemd state?  Why are we moving away from the systemd state?  Please answer in your commit message.  From my perspective, systemd is more "standard", so this is a step backward.

Lengtjy discord discussion but IMO, we have a precedent of abstracting systemd states behind services like x86-power-control/phosphor-state-manager. You can see it in functions like getHostState() and getChassisState(). We could put all the logic in bmcweb to determine if the BMC is being updated or has a failed critical service (Quiesced) but that a) adds a lot more code to bmcweb and b) goes away from our design of allowing other repositories abstract away the complexity. Commit  message should be updated to identify these use cases and why using bmc-state-manager for this abstraction is a benefit.
Is this present on all BMCs?

As written, you've now imposed a hard dependency on bmc-state-manager, but fails to handle the race of if bmcweb comes up before bmc-state-manager.  Considering that folks are using this API to determine if the bmc is "up", and system-wise, we don't really want a failure in bmc-state-manager to cause bmcweb to lock up (given that bmcweb has a lot of debug use cases) we need to think through these paths a little in this implementation.  if bmc-state-manager fails
what do we do?  Can we have reasonable default behavior?
This is hardcoded the same as before in all possible paths.  I suspect this can move back to just being hardcoded where it was prior to this patch.

Yeah, there was a lot of debate on this during the review but final agreement was to just leave to always On so makes sense to just put it back, or at top of this function if we want it all in one place.
Please adapt and consider the existing health designs.  I'm pretty sure it's required in this case.

Ed

I see this is the way followed in most of the places..
I don't think we need any other health designs in this case
Yeah, precedent for chassis and host health has been a function like this. Were you looking for something else Ed?

I think Ed is talking about https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/designs/redfish-health-rolllup.md 
But https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/search?q=health-%3Epopulate is only used in some of the resources. It is in this resource on line 2102. Setting the Manager Health based on BMCState makes more sense to me then using redfish-health-rolllup.md
Commit message updated to document why health was done this way
Need to find a way to summarize in a single line no more then 50 chars
This kind of just jumps into things, let me take a stab and giving a bit more background.
But we lost the PowerState, do we care?
hard coded up in the function on line 1949
Kind of unexpected a unsupported D-Bus state is Enabled/Ok but I guess I am okay, if someone adds a new BMCState, they will add an else if here and support the new state.

In the above design, it calls out a obmc-bmc-service-quiesce.target that is used.  Considering that the existing code is already checking the systemd targets, why don't we just add that to the list and check it as well?  That seems more in line with what a normal linux distro would do.

See above points on phosphor-state-manager providing abstractions. Why should bmcweb even know the system uses systemd? I feel like we just have fundamental differences here (and neither is going to convince the other) so we probably just have to abandon this (and continue to carry downstream).
Why does xyz.openbmc_project.State.BMC own this state?  Shouldn't the firmware update daemon (that bmcweb already interacts with) maintain this state?

Feels like we're talking past ourselves a bit which makes me think there's just a fundamental divide in our thinking here. phophor-state-manager was created to abstract the BMC, Chassis, and Host states (as well as with providing some operations like powering on/off and rebooting). x86-power-control does the same for chassis and host. We could have bmcweb do all of the logic contained in those apps (look at systemd targets, pgood, host BIOS post codes, ...) but we don't because that's the job of those repositories. xyz.openbmc_project.State.BMC doesn't own the state, it provides an abstraction of it, providing a holistic view of the BMC state.
What logic?  Checking to see if a firmware update is in progress through the dbus APIs?  That doesn't really seem like logic.
Yes, checking quiesce target, checking code update state. This is logic, and with this abstraction, it can change in the future without bmcweb needding to be involved in the back end details.

I'm not quite understanding this statement.  Today, bmcweb lets systemd abstract away these complexities, which seems reasonable, given that in the design, that's systemds job.  What I don't see in the above is why we're adding yet another middle daemon to the design, and why this state can't exist from systemd, considering we already have code to do it, and systemd owns the concept of "started" for the system.

So it seems like you're saying, if the BMC state were to get more complicated (like chassis ans host are), you'd be ok with the abstraction, but since it's just systemd checks, you'd prefer to keep all that logic in bmcweb? From my perspective, we'd just be copy/pasting code form phosphor-state-manger into bmcweb. Why do that when we already have it all done and abstracted in xyz.openbmc_project.State.BMC?

While this goes through quite a bit of history, and has a lot of good details, it still doesn't list WHY this change is being made.  To ask in other terms, if we didn't merge this patch, what does the user lose out on?
More details added to commit message.
This latest patch was just a rebase due to merge conflict. CI fail was something infrastructure related so I retriggered.
Like we talked about on discord, it's not clear why we're completely removing the systemd checker.  If systemd is still starting up, I suspect the state is still starting, right?

bmcweb tends to returns what it has available, or a reasonable default. This logic is already done in xyz.openbmc_project.State.BMC so return a reasonable default and simplify some bmcweb code. If we keep it, your next question will be, why not just look for quiesce and code update too :) (i.e. where do we draw the line)

So if bmcweb starts before xyz.openbmc_project.State.BMC, the user sees

"State": "Enabled"

then immediately sees state "Quiesced".
Hmm , don't get that. Why does it immediately see "Quiesced" in this case?

So if bmcweb is up before  xyz.openbmc_project.State.BMC, the user would see Enabled.. But when xyz.openbmc_project.State.BMC comes up, the user would then see "Starting" / "Quiesced" / "Enabled" based now on the information coming from xyz.openbmc_project.State.BMC.. so yes, it could go from "Enabled" to "Quiesced" but that seems reasonable to me based on the old behavior and what we want here.

> but that seems reasonable to me based on the old behavior and what we want here.

That seems like it would completely defeat the purpose of this if it's inconsistent?

What is the alternative? don't have a default here? i.e. if don't get back something from xyz.openbmc_project.State.BMC, just leave these properties off? Leave off State and Health, have PowerState still?

I am fine with that but this did have a default before.. 


> That seems like it would completely defeat the purpose of this if it's inconsistent?

For hoststate, you could move from some Enabled/On/Poweringon state to Quiesced (e.g. hoststate is on, then hoststate goes to that Quiesced target.). Why is inconsistent such a concern here for bmc state?

> What is the alternative? don't have a default here? i.e. if don't get back something from xyz.openbmc_project.State.BMC, just leave these properties off? Leave off State and Health, have PowerState still?

I assume this is the direction we want?
My personal alternative is to rely on things that we already know are up and functional (ie systemd) to determine the "upness" of the system, and totally avoid this race condition.
